Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2014 06:54AM Bluemnm wrote: Arenswife, I know exactly how you feel, we had been trying to have kids for 5 years prior to my diagnosis. I already had guilt over that and this just added to it, especially when other people say stupid things like why don't you adopt or maybe it'll still happen.  I have been upfront with everyone about my diagnosis too so when they say stuff like that, I just think they are in denial.  My husband has been great about it and our poor dog has to suffer through being treated like a kid sometime.  I wish you all the best and do take the advice of putting yourself first, I've had to learn to do that too.  Hugs  Sarah
Posts.Title: I don't/can't have kids & I'm 36 & frozen by fear arenswife stagefree

Posts.Content: Bluemnm wrote: hi all,  I am currently in the hospital for a few days now due to neutropenia fever.  I spoke to my oncologists today and he is thinking he is gonna just stop chemo all together and put me on tamoxifen..  I had one A/C chemo left and then was going to do 6 weeks of Taxol.  I'm a little worried about doing this and think we should maybe at least of the taxol.  I know from what I read that chemo is usually first line treatment for younger women so I have concerns.  Any thoughts???  Thanks!!  All's well,﻿ what's a rainy day Never mind that cloud Behind that cloud You'll find a golden ray. Dx 4/23/2014, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Chemotherapy 4/28/2014 AC Radiation Therapy 6/12/2014 External: Bone Hormonal Therapy 7/23/2014 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 7/23/2014 Zoladex (goserelin) Radiation Therapy 12/28/2015 External: Bone Radiation Therapy 8/2/2016 External: Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 07:03PM Bluemnm wrote: My nausea was awful on A/C,  it took many calls to the onc and trying a few different nausea meds  to find what worked for me.  Ativan helped a lot too as others have said.   I felt the same way you do at first though, but it did get better.  Try to keep some crackers on your stomach and some ginger tea too if you can.  Praying you find something that helps with the nausea and that you feel better soon.  Hugs. Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2015 07:51AM Bluemnm wrote: I like this thread, thanks for starting it. 1. My mom and dad. My parents are the most hard working and generous people that I know, both of them have struggled with so much but they never complain. They have both had their own cancers (dad still does) and they have already had to bury my sister who was killed by a drunk driver when she was 26. I worry about who will take care of them, I have siblings but they are both busy with their kids and such. 2. My husband, although we have been married since 2008 he was deployed for almost 3 years total of the time we have been married. It still feels like we are newlyweds and I want more time to spend with him and travel, etc. We just bought a house last year and it seems like our life was just starting. I love him so much. 3. My nieces and nephews. I have 11 nieces and nephews that I am very close to, they are such good kids. My oldest nephew lived with me some after my sister died, so he is like a son to me. 4. My younger sister. When we were younger we didn't get along, but over the past few years we have become closer. She just got engaged and I want to be around for her wedding. 5. There are still many places I want to see and things I want to do!

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2016 09:41AM - edited Aug 26, 2016 09:41AM by Bluemnm Hi Pixie, Welcome to our group. I was diagnosed at 35 and will be turning 38 in a few months. I am 96% ER positive and have responded well to my treatment. I recommend checking out https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... for a copy of BestBirds guide to metastatic cancer. It is very helpful for discussions with your onc. In regards to travel I have taken many trips since my diagnosis, I just got back from an anniversary trip to vegas/grand canyon. So travel definitely is possible. I hope all goes well with your onc appt! Sarah
